page.title: 1.1.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will experiment with expressions and equations to model a situation: planning a pizza party. For instance, what are the relevant quantities when planning for a pizza party? Are these quantities fixed or do they vary? How they might relate to one another? Are there any limitations or constraints on how much pizza should be ordered?

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Tell which quantities in a situation can vary and which ones cannot.
  • Explain the meaning of the term “constraint.”
  • Use letters and numbers to write expressions representing the quantities in a situation.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 1.1.1: Understanding Value 
  • 1.1.2: Creating Expressions to Estimate Cost, Part 1
  • 1.1.2: Self Check 
  • 1.1.3: Understanding Constraints
  • 1.1.3: Self Check 
  • 1.1.4: Creating Expressions to Estimate Cost, Part 2

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 1.1.5: Practice
  • 1.1.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 1.1.1: Understanding Value
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Here are some letters and what they represent. All costs are in dollars.

    • \( m \) represents the cost of a main dish.
    • \( n \) represents the number of side dishes.
    • \( s \) represents the cost of a side dish.
    • \( t \) represents the total cost of a meal.

  1. Discuss with a partner: What does each equation mean in this situation?
    1. \( m=7.50 \)
    2. \( m = s + 4.50 \)
    3. \( ns = 6 \)
    4. \( m + ns = t \)

  2. Write a new equation that could be true in this situation.

Enter your answer to the second question here:

Your answers may vary, but some equations that could be true for this situation include the following:

\( m = 2 \)
\( m − s = 4.5 \)
\( m + 6 = 13.5 \)

page.title: 1.1.2: Creating Expressions to Estimate Cost, Part 1
page.contents:
Activity

Imagine your class is having a pizza party. 

Work with your group to plan what to order and to estimate what the party would cost.


  1. Record your group’s plan and cost estimate. What would it take to convince the class to go with your group’s plan? Be prepared to explain your reasoning.

  2. Write down one or more expressions that show how your group’s cost estimate was calculated.
    1. In your expression(s), are there quantities that might change on the day of the party? Which ones?
    2. Rewrite your expression(s), replacing the quantities that might change with letters. Be sure to specify what the letters represent.

Making a Real-World Connection

Find a pizza place near you and ask about the diameter and cost of at least two sizes of pizza. Compare the cost per square inch of the sizes.

Enter your answer here:

Which pizza size is the better deal? Understanding how to write expressions can help you save money!

page.title: 1.1.2: Self Check
page.contents: A ninth-grade class is ordering pizza for lunch. There are \( n \) students in the class. Each slice of pizza costs $3 and the delivery fee is $8. Which expression represents the total cost if each student gets 2 slices of pizza?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Each student gets 2 slices of pizza. Multiply the cost of one slice \( (3n) \) by 2. Also, add the delivery fee of $8. The answer is \( (2)3n + 8 \).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The cost must include a delivery fee of $8. The answer is \((2)3n + 8 \).
That’s correct! Check yourself: The expression that represents the cost of 2 slices of pizza for n students is \( (2)3n \). Adding the delivery fee of $8 results in the expression \( (2)3n + 8 \).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Each student gets 2 slices of pizza. Multiply the cost of one slice by 2. The answer is \( (2)3n + 8 \).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 1.1.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Translate an English Phrase to an Algebraic Expression

You can use the following operation symbols to translate English phrases into algebraic expressions. 

Operation

Phrase

Expression

Addition

a plus b

the sum of a and b

a increased by b

b more than a

the total of a and b

b added to a

\( a + b \)

Subtraction

a minus b

the difference of a and b

a decreased by b

b less than a

b subtracted from a

\( a − b \)

Multiplication

a times b

the product of a and b

twice a

\( a⋅b, ab, a(b), (a)(b) \)


\( 2a \)

Division

a divided by b

the quotient of a and b

the ratio of a and b

b divided into a

\( a÷b, a/b \)


Look closely at these phrases using the four operations:

the sum of \( a \) and \( b \)
the difference of \( a \) and \( b \)
the product of \( a \) and \( b \)
the quotient of \( a \) and \( b \)

Each phrase tells us to operate on two numbers. Look for the words of and and to find the numbers.

Later in this course, we’ll apply our skills in algebra to solving applications. The first step will be to translate an English phrase to an algebraic expression. You can see how to do this in the following example:

The length of a rectangle is 14 less than the width. Let \( w \) represent the width of the rectangle. Write an expression for the length of the rectangle.

Write a phrase about the length of the rectangle.

14 less than the width

Substitute w for “the width.”

\( w \)

Rewrite less than as subtracted from.

14 subtracted from w

Translate the phrase into algebra.

\( w − 14 \)

Try It: Translate an English Phrase to an Algebraic Expression

Translate the following into an algebraic expression: 

June has dimes and quarters in her purse. The number of dimes is seven less than four times the number of quarters. Let \( q \) represent the number of quarters. Write an expression for the number of dimes.

Write down your answer, then select the Solution button to check your work.

Solution

Here is how to translate this into an algebraic expression:

Write a phrase about the number of dimes.

seven less than four times the number of quarters

Substitute \( q \) for the number of quarters.

7 less than 4 times \( q \)

Translate \(4\) times \( q \).

7 less than \( 4q \)

Translate the phrase into algebra.

\( 4q − 7 \)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking.
Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 1.1.3: Understanding Constraints
page.contents:
Activity

A constraint is something that limits what is possible or reasonable in a situation.

For example, one constraint in a pizza party might be the number of slices of pizza each person could have, \(s\). We can write \( s<4 \) to say that each person gets fewer than 4 slices.

  1. Look at the expressions you wrote when planning the pizza party earlier.
    1. Choose an expression that uses one or more letters.
    2. For each letter, determine what values would be reasonable. (For instance, could the value be a non-whole number? A number greater than 50? A negative number? Exactly 2?)

  2. Write equations or inequalities that represent some constraints in your pizza party plan. If a quantity must be an exact value, use the = symbol. If it must be greater than or less than a certain value to be reasonable, use the \( > \) or \( < \) symbol.

Enter your answer to the second question here:

FEEDBACK: 

Your answers may vary, but some equations or inequalities that represent some constraints in your pizza party plan could include the following:

\( c = 7.50 \) or \( c > 7.50 \) and \( c < 12 \)
\( p > 11 \) and \( p < 20 \)


Video: Writing an Inequality for the Constraint

Watch the following video to learn more about constraints.

page.title: 1.1.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Inequalities

On the number line, the numbers get larger as they go from left to right. The number line can be used to explain the symbols “\( < \)” and “\( > \).”

Inequality
\( a < b \)  is read “ \( a \) is less than \( b \). ” \( a \) is to the left of \( b \) on the number line.


\( a > b \)  is read “\( a \)  is greater than \( b \). ” \( a \) is to the right of \( b \) on the number line

The expressions \( a < b \) or \( a > b \) can be read from left to right or right to left, though in English we usually read from left to right. In general, \( a < b \) is equivalent to \( b > a \). 

For example \( 7 < 11 \) is equivalent to \( 11 > 7 \). And \( a > b \) is equivalent to \( b < a \). For example \( 17 > 4 \) is equivalent to \( 4 < 17 \).

Inequality Symbols    

Words

\( a ≠ b \)

a is not equal to b

\( a < b \)

a is less than b

\( a ≤ b \)

a is less than or equal to b

\( a > b \)

a is greater than b

\( a ≥ b \)

 a is greater than or equal to b

Let’s look at some specific examples:

Algebra

English Translation

\( 17 ≤ 26 \)

17 is less than or equal to 26

\( 12 > 27 ÷ 3 \)

12 is greater than 27 divided by 3

\( y + 7 < 19 \)

y plus 7 is less than 19

Try It: Inequalities

Translate the following expressions from algebra to English: 

\( 14 ≤ 27 \)
\( 12 > 4 ÷ 2 \)
\( x − 7 < 1 \)

Write down your answer, then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to translate the expressions into English:

Algebra

English Translation

\( 14 ≤ 27 \)

14 is less than or equal to 27

\( 12 > 4 ÷ 2 \)

12 is greater than 4 divided by 2

\( x − 7 < 1 \)

x minus 7 is less than 1

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking.
Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 1.1.4: Creating Expressions to Estimate Cost, Part 2
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

At the end of the school year, all students in the ninth grade are invited to an ice cream party. Use the skills you learned from planning a pizza party to answer the following:

  1. Write an expression that could represent an estimated cost for the party. Use at least one letter. State what each part of the expression represents.

  2. Choose a letter in your expression. Describe the values that would be reasonable for the quantity that the letter represents.

Enter your answers to these two questions here:

Your answers may vary, but here are some sample responses to compare your answers.

  1. Sample responses:
    • \( 1.50n + 0.08(1.50n) \). There are \( n \) students in the ninth grade. A packaged ice cream cone is about $1.50, and tax is about 8%.
    • \( \frac {125}{6} \cdot 5 + 6(3) + p \). There are 125 students in the ninth grade. Suppose a tub of ice cream costs $5 and is enough for 6 students. A pack of 24 cones costs about $3, and 6 packs are needed. A pack of 150 paper napkins costs \( p \) dollars.
  2. Sample responses:
    • A whole number between 90 and 100 is a reasonable value for the number of students in ninth grade, or \( 90 \leq n \geq 100 \)
    • A number less than $4 but more than $1 is reasonable for the cost of a pack of paper napkins, or \( 1 < n < 4 \).

page.title: 1.1.3: Self Check
page.contents: Marcus works \( s \) hours per week stocking shelves. He works \( m \) hours per week mowing lawns. Marcus works at least 8 hours per week stocking shelves. He works at most a total of 20 hours per week. Which of the following represent constraints for this situation?

answer.answer_text: \( s + m ≥ 20; s ≥ 8 \)
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: At most 20 hours means 20 hours or less. Use the less than or equal to symbol. The correct answer is \( s + m ≤ 20; s ≥ 8 \).

answer.answer_text: \( s + m ≤ 20; s ≥ 8 \)
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: At most 20 hours means 20 hours or less, which uses the less than or equal to symbol. At least 8 hours means 8 hours or more, which uses the greater than or equal to symbol.

answer.answer_text: \( s + m ≥ 20; s ≤ 8 \)
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: At most 20 hours means 20 hours or less. Use the less than or equal to symbol. At least 8 hours means 8 hours or more. Use the greater than or equal to symbol. The correct answer is \( s + m ≤ 20; s ≥ 8 \).

answer.answer_text: \( s + m ≤ 20; s ≤ 8 \)
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: At least 8 hours means 8 hours or more Use the greater than or equal to symbol. The correct answer is \( s + m ≤ 20; s ≥ 8 \).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 1.1.5: Practice
page.contents:
1. To support a local senior citizens center, a student club sent a flier home to the n students in the school. The flier said, “Please bring in money to support the senior citizens center. Paper money and coins accepted!” Their goal is to raise T dollars.

Match each quantity to an expression, an equation, or an inequality that describes it.

a. The dollar amount the club would have if they reached half of their goal:

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.1.2 - are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(0.5T\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

b. The dollar amount the club would have if every student at the school donated 50 cents to the cause

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.1.2 - are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(0.5n\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

c. The dollar amount the club could donate if they made $50 more than their goal

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.1.2 - are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(T+50\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

d. The dollar amount the club would still need to raise to reach its goal after every student at the school donated 50 cents

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.1.2 - are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(T-0.5n\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

e. The dollar amount the club would have if half of the students at the school each gave 50 cents

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.1.2 - are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(0.25n\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

2. Each of the 10 students in the baking club made 2 chocolate cakes for a fundraiser. They all used the same recipe, using C cups of flour in total.

Write an expression that represents the amount of flour required for one cake.

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 1.1.2 to test your understanding, then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(\frac c{20}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

3. A student club started a fundraising effort to support animal rescue organizations. The club sent an information flier home to the n students in the school. It says, “We welcome donations of any amount, including any change you could spare!” Their goal is to raise T dollars and to donate to a cat shelter and a dog shelter.

a. The dollar amount the club would have if they reached one-fourth of their goal

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.1.2 - are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(\frac14T\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

b. The dollar amount the club would have if every student at the school donated a quarter to the cause

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.1.2 - are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is A-2, B-5, C-4, D-3, E-1. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

c. The dollar amount the club could donate to the cat shelter if they reached their goal and gave a quarter of the total donation to a dog shelter

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.1.2 - are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is A-2, B-5, C-4, D-3, E-1. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

d. The dollar amount the club would still need to raise to reach its goal after every student at the school donated a quarter

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.1.2 - are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is A-2, B-5, C-4, D-3, E-1. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

e. The dollar amount the club would have if three-fourths of the students at the school each gave 50 cents

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.1.2 - are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is A-2, B-5, C-4, D-3, E-1. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

4. Determine if each is an expression or an equation : 

a. 3(x − 7) = 27

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 1.1.3 to test your understanding, then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is equation. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

b. 5(4y − 2) − 7

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 1.1.3 to test your understanding, then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is expression. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

c. y³ ÷ 14

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 1.1.3 to test your understanding, then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is expression. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

d. 4x − 6 = 22

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 1.1.3 to test your understanding, then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is equation. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

For questions 5-9, translate the English phrase into an algebraic expression.

5. the difference of \(14x^2\;\) and 13

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.1.2 - are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is b. \(14x^2\;-13\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

 

6. the quotient of \(12x\) and 2

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 1.1.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(\frac{12x}2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

 

 

7. the sum of \( 17y^2 \) and 19

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.1.2 - are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(17y^2+19\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

 

 

8. the product of 7 and \( y \)

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 1.1.2 to test you understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(7y\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

 

 

9. In the following exercises, determine if each is an expression or an equation. 

a. 9 · 6 = 54

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.1.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is equation. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

b. 7 · 9 = 63

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.1.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is equation. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

c. 5 · 4 + 3

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.1.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is expression. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

10. Eric has rock and classical CDs in his car. The number of rock CDs is 3 more than the number of classical CDs. Let c represent the number of classical CDs. Select the expression that represents the number of rock CDs.

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 1.1.2 to test your understanding, then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is c + 3. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

 

 

11. Greg has nickels and pennies in his pocket. The number of pennies is seven less than twice the number of nickels. Let n represent the number of nickels. Select the expression that represents the number of pennies.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.1.2 - are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 2n - 7. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 1.1.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Tell which quantities in a situation can vary and which ones cannot.
  • Explain the meaning of the term “constraint.”
  • Use letters and numbers to write expressions representing the quantities in a situation.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 1.1.1: Understanding Value 
    • In this activity, you wrote equations to solve problems about a meal. The big thing you learned is that an equation is a statement that an expression has the same value as another expression. An equation can have letters, numbers, or a mix of letters and numbers. 
  • 1.1.2: Creating Expressions to Estimate Cost, Part 1
    • In this activity, you learned how expressions could represent the quantities in a situation like planning a pizza party. You also saw how expressions could change if quantities changed.
  • 1.1.2: Self Check 
  • 1.1.3: Understanding Constraints
    • In this activity, you continued working with the pizza party and learned that a constraint is something that limits what is possible or reasonable in a situation.
  • 1.1.3: Self Check 
  • 1.1.4: Creating Expressions to Estimate Cost, Part 2
    • In this activity, you wrote expressions and examined constraints for the cost of an ice cream party for the ninth-grade class.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 1.1.5: Practice

Checking In 

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
